summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The Government argues for an earlier deadline for Maxwell to file a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412, which governs the admissibility of evidence about a victim's sexual behavior, to ensure proper review before trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, for whom the defense seeks to file a Rule 412 motion regarding victim evidence.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this letter from the Government is addressed, regarding the scheduling of a Rule 412 motion.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding.
Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Maxwell.

events.title: Government's Scheduling Letter Filed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a letter with the court arguing for an earlier deadline for the defense to file a Rule 412 motion.

events.title: Defendant's Letter to Court
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel writes to the court to confirm a November 15, 2021 deadline for filing a Rule 412 motion.

events.title: Government Produces Witness and Evidence Materials
events.description: The Government produces its witness list, Giglio material, Jencks Act material, and Rule 404(b) notice to the defense, seven weeks before trial.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Government is opposing the defense's proposed November 15, 2021 deadline for filing a Rule 412 motion, arguing the court has authority to set an earlier deadline.
Federal Rule of Evidence 412 restricts evidence about a victim's other sexual behavior to protect victim privacy, with exceptions that require a pretrial motion.
The Government argues an earlier deadline is needed to properly investigate and hold necessary in-camera hearings before trial, especially with multiple victim witnesses.
The document cites several legal precedents (Rivera, Andrews, Backman, Smith) supporting a court's discretion to set Rule 412 motion deadlines more than 14 days before trial.
The trial schedule, combined with the Thanksgiving holiday, is cited as a practical reason against the defense's proposed late filing date.
